cab.content: REPARTITION DES DEPENSES DE LA SOCIETE DES nations memorandum DU SECRETAIRE GENERALLeague of NationsALLOCATION OF EXPENSES OF THE LEAGUE OF nations memorandum BY THE SECRETARY-GENERAL D 18SOCIETY DES nations Tmdiiclion.]REPARTITION DES DEPENSES DE LA SOCIETE DES nations memorandum du Secretaire General.Une Commission avait ete nominee a la Conference de Bruxelles pour exami-ner quels principes devaient presider a la repartition des depenses de la Societe. Elle etait arrivee a eertaines conclusions rapportees dans la piece No 41 de TAs-semblee.Au cours des seances de cette Commission, 1'idee fut emise que les modifica-tions pour rendre le systeine actuel plus equitable et 1'accorder avec les besoins de la Societe des Nations, pouvaient etre faites sans amendement au Pacte, pourvu que Ton put persuader a 1'Union Postale Universelle (dont la constitution admet sans difficulte des modifications) d'adopter un systeme de repartition qui put satisfaire la Societe.On trouvera ci-joint (Annexe 1) un court memoine sur le cote juridique de cette question, telle que ^avait soulevee le Delegue de la Suede a la seance d'ou-verture de la. Commission, le 18 novembre.La Commission, et eventuellement TAssemblee, se trouvenl done en presence de 1'alternative suivante, selon que les conclusions du memoire annexe seraient adoptees ou non :1. - Si Ton admet que les membres de la Societe des Nations sont tenus par le Pacte d'accepler lechelle de 1'Union Postale Universelle, telle qn'elle existait au 10 Janvier 1920, jusqua ce qu'un amendement ait ete formule au Pacte, il faut qu'un tel amendement soil mis en vigueur, conformement aux regies de proce-dure indiquees clans 1'ai'ticle 26 du Pacte.2. - Si Ton adopte 1'autre point de vue, rAssemblee est dans 1'obligalion de transmettre a la Conference de 1'Union Postale Universelle tel projet de repar-tition nouveau iqu'elle aurait acceptee, projet qui entrerait en vigueur des son adoption par 1'Union Postale Universelle. LEAGUE OF NATIONSDALLOCATION OF EXPENSES OF THE LEAGUE OF nations memorandum by the Secretary-General.A Committee of the Brussels Conference was appointed to consider the pvin-ciples to be adopted in regard to the allocation of the Expenses of the League and certain conclusions were arrived at which are embodied in Assembly Document No 41.While this Commission was in session it was suggested that the changes needed to make the present system more equitable and in accordance with the necessities of the League of Nations could be brought about without an amend-ment of the Covenant if the Universal Postal Union (whose constitution permits changes to be made without difficulty) could be persuaded to adopt a method of distribution which would satisfy the League.A short memorandum is annexed (Annex I) on the legal aspect of this point, a question as- to which was raised by the Swedish Delegate at the opening Meeting of the Commission on the 18th November.Two alternative modes of procedure are thus before the Committee and, even-tually the Assembly, according as (to whether) the conclusions of the annexed memorandum are adopted or not :1. - If it be agreed that the Members of the League are bound; by the Cove-nant to adhere to the scale of the Universal Postal Union as it existed on the 10th January, 1920, until an amendment shall have been made in the Covenant, such an amendment must be carried into effect in accordance with the procedure indicated in Article 26 of the Covenant.2. - If the opposite view be adopted, it will be necessary for the Assembly to communicate to the Conference of the Universal Postal Union any new schedule which the Assembly may accept, and this can come into effect as soon as it has been adopted by the Universal Postal Union.L. of N, - D 18."- Imp. Centralo. - 2A/20 II n'y a done de difference que dans la marchc a suivre, puisque dans les deux cas la seule question effective soumise a' TAssemblee est de savoir si elle enlend adopter ou non un nouveau projel de repartition, et dans Taffirmative lcquel. Pratiquement il serait sans aucun doute plus commode d'adopter la deu-xieme solution. L/avantage serait de permellrc 1'enlree en vigueur du nouveau pro jet a une date nettement precisee, c'est-a-dire au moment de son adoption par 1'Union Postale Universelle, tandis que d'apresi le reglement indique dans 1'annexe 1, il ne peut entrer en vigueur avant sa ratification par tous les membres de la Societe des Nations, dont les represcntants composent le Gonseil, et par la majorite de ceux dont les representants composent 1'Assemblee.Gomme suite aux propositions presentees par le Comite de la Conference finan-ciere de Bruxelles, le Gouvernement Suisse a ete pressenti officieusement et a manifeste sa bonne volonte. II s'est declare pret a examiner favorablement, d'accord avec le Bureau Central de 1'Union Postale a Berne, la possibilite d'apporter les modifications necessaires dans le sens des demandes de la Societe des Nations. L'Union Postale Universelle qui, a la requete de la Commission, a designe un Comite charge d'examiner ces questions, s'attend done a recevoir de la Societe des Nations 1'indication des diangements projeles.Les principes reconumandes par la Commission de Bruxelles ont ete mainte-nant appliques a 1'elaboration de tableaux precis tablis par le Secretariat.Ci-joint un memoire a distribuer, indiquant les resultats obtenus. The difference is thus entirely one of procedure since in either case the only substantive questions before the Assembly are whether it should adopt a new sche-dule or not, and if so what that schedule should be. In practice it would no doubt be more convenient to adopt the second alternative as regards procedure. This would offer the advantage that the new schedule would come into force at a clearly defined moment, viz., at the moment of its adoption by the Universal Pos-lal Union, whereas under the -procedure of (1) it will not come into force until it shall have been ratified by all the Members of the League whose representa-lives compose the Council, and by a majority of those whose representatives compose the Assembly.As a result of the proposals put forward by the Committee of the Brussels Financial Conference, the Swiss Government was approached unofficially in the matter, and expressed its willingness, in conjunction with the Central Office of the Postal Union at Berne, to consider favourably the possibility of introducing the necessary changes in accordance with the requirements of the League. The Uni-versal Postal Union which on the request of the Commission has appointed a Committee to consider the problems, is therefore waiting to receive from the League an indication of these changes.The principles recommended by the Brussels Commission have now been worked out into definite schedules by the Secretariat and a Memorandum (Annex II) containing the results is circulated herewith. I Traduclion.)ANNEXE INOTE RELATIVE A ^INTERPRETATION DES TERMES DU DERNIER PARAGRAPHE DE L'ART. G 1)U PACTELa question qui m'est posee est la suivante: - Le dernier paragraphs de 1'artiole 6 du Pacte portant que ^ les depenses du Secretariat sont supportees par les membres de la Societe dans la proportion etablie pour le Bureau International de 1'Union Postale Universelle yy, ce texte implique-t-il quune modification appor-tee a la Convention detablissement de l'Union Postale Universelle, serait egalement ^applicable a la repartition des depenses du Secretariat de la Societe des Nations ?Je reponds que la repartition des depenses du Secretariat devrait etre faite conf ormement a la repartition des depenses du Bureau International de 1'UnionPos-lale Universelle telle qiielle existait a 1'epoque oil le Pacte fnt mis en vigueur.On ne peut supposer que lesi Membres de la Societe ont accepte une methods de repartition qui leur etait inconnue au moment ou ils ont souscrit aux conditions imposees par le Pacte.Cette interpretation est explicitement conforme au texte frangais dont voici la teneur : ^ Lesi depenses du; Secretariat sont supportees par les Membres de la Societe dans la proportion etablie pour le Bureau International de 1'Union Postale Uni-verselle)), et semble etre imipliquee dans la redaotion anglaise.II semble done qu'une modification dans l'echelle de repartition des depenses du Secretariat de la Societe appellerait une modification du dernier paragraphe de l'Art. 6 du Pacte.Je ne veux pas omettre de faire remarquer que des autorites eminentes ont une opinion contraire. Leur point de vue est le suivant : % Le texle anglais du dernier paragraphe de 1'Art. 6 est redige en termes tres generaux, et ne corro-bore pas 1'opinion selon laquelle, jusqu'a amendement du Pacte, les membres seraient tenus de se partager les depenses, conf ormement au reglement en vigueur en 1919. Ce texte ne contient aucun mot ni aucune expression restreignant les limites de la repartition a celles de 1'Union Postale, telles qu'elles existaient le jour ou le Pacte est entre en vigueur, ou excluant provisoirement le systeme postal de repartition, en taut que facteurs decisifs de la repartition des depenses.))Etant donne cette divergence d'opinion, j'estime que les membres de la Societe peuvent juger oppcrtun de la faire examiner par leurs Comites techniques. J'ai tendance a croire que la bonne interpretation du texte anglaisi conduit a l'opinion que j'ai eu 1'honneur d'exprimer au debut de la presente note.$3 Novembte 1920.(SigneJ VAN HAMEL Directeur de la Section Legale. ,) ANNEX memorandum REGARDING THE INTERPRETATION OF THE LAST PARAGRAPH OF ARTICLE 6 OF THE COVENANTThe question placed before me is the following: - Does the last paragraph of Article 6 of the Covenant, saying that :t The expenses of the Secretarial shall hi borne by the Members of the League in accordance with the apportionment of the expenses of the International Bureau of the Universal Postal Union))imply that a modification in the scale of apportionment brought about by a modi-fication of the Convention of the International Postal Union will also apply to the apportionment of the expenses of the Secretariat of the League ?My answer to this question is that the apportionment of the expenses of the Secretariat should be made in accordance with the apportionment of the expenses of the International Bureau of the Universal Postal Union such as it nuts at the. time when the Covenant came into force.Members of the League cannot be presumed to have accepted methods of allo-cation with which they were not acquainted at the moment when they accepted the obligations of the Covenant.This interpretation is explicitly in accordance with the French text, reading as follows :z Les depenses du Secretariat sont supportees par les Membres de la Societe dans la proportion etablie pour le. Bureau International de 1'Union Poslale Univer-selleand seems to be implied in the English wording.An alteration in the scale of apportionment of the expenses of the Secreta-proletariat of the League would therefore seem to require a modification of the last para-graph of Article 6 of the Covenant.Certain eminent authorities have expressed, however, a contrary view. In their opinion, the English text of the last paragraph in Article 6 is in very general terms and gives no support to the view that until the Covenant is amended the Members are bound to share expenses in accordance with the plan in force in 1919. That text contains no word or phrase which restricts it to the Postal apportionment existing on the day when the Covenant came into force, or which excludes the postal apportionment scheme for the time being as the determining factor in the distribution of expenses.In view of this divergence of opinion, I think that Members of the League may find it desirable to have the question examined by their advisers. I am inclined to hold that the better interpretation of the English text leads to the view I have expressed at the beginning of this Memorandum.(Signed) VAN HAMEL,Director, Legal Section.23rd November 1920. ANNEXE IIMEMOIRE SLIR LA REPARTITION DES DEPENSES DE LA SOCIETE DES NATIONSLa Commission de la Conference de Bruxelles, qpi a examine le probleme des regies a adapter pour la repartition des depenses de la Societe entre ses differents membres, a etudie diverses propositions fixant le principe de la contribution, d'apres la valeur des benefices recus.(*) Ces projets, toutefois, furent ecar-tes pour faire place au principe general de taxation, etabli dapres la capacite de paiement. La vraie mesure (le cette capacite de paiement est discutee dans le rapport de la Conimission. Ce rapport concluait qu'en 1'absence de statistiquesi pouvant servir de criterium veritable, en matiere de revenus natio-naux, le meilleur guide approximatif consisterait en un tableau combinant: a) les chiffres de recettes nettes pour 1913, b) le chiffre de la population, sous cette reserve que, dans la partie du tableau relatif a la population, le chiffre le plus fort ne depasse, en aucun cas, celui du societaire europeen possedant la popula-tion la plus nombreuse. Rien n'etait propose pour le choix de la date des recen-sements; mais, comme les chiffres d'avant-guerre sont, dans bien des cas, depour-vus de toute valeur, par suite des changements territoriaux, il est evident qu'il faut se servir des chiffres reels ou evalues pour Tannee 1919. Tons les Etats Membres de la Societe ont ete pries de lui faire connaitre le chiffre de leur population au 31 decembre 1919, et ces releves ont ete utilises clans les calculs qui suivent.La methode suivie pour combiner ces series de chiffres n'a pas ete definiti-movement etablie; mais Ton propose d'evaluer la population et les revenus de cha-que Elat en les rapiportant, sous forme de pourcentages, a la population et aux reve-pus globaux. Cette proposition a ete adoptee dans le travail ci-dessous.On constata que ce tableau approximatif ne fournirait pas une evaluation exacte des ressources de chaque pays. On a pense cependant que, sauf cas excep-tionnels, il rangerail a peu pres les differenls Etats, selon 1'ordre cVimportance de leurs revenus.Les deux premieres colonnes des Tableaux I et II presentent respectivement les chiffres de la population et des receltes nettes, indiquees d'abord en monnaies nationales, puis en dollars (les colonnes suivantes contiennent d'autres rensei-gnements statistiques qui interessent la situation economique des diffenents Etats.) Dans plusieurs cas, lorsque des changements tcrritoriaux ont eu lieu, les chiffres de recettes ont du etre retablis en evaluant, par tetes, lc chiffre relatif aux popu-lations passees sous une souverainete differente.(*) Ainsi, on a propose de considerer les depenses cVarmement d'une nation comme uue indication des risqnes qu'elle court d'etre entrainee dans une guerre et qiie ces depenses donnent la mesure, en consequence, du besoin qu'a cette nation des services de la Societe. 330ANNEX 11memorandum on the allocation of the expensesof the leagueThe Committee of the Brussels Conference which considered the problem of the principles to be adopted in allocating the expenses of the League among its various Members, considered various suggestions based upon the principle, of benefit received. (*) These, however, were finally discarded in favour of the general taxation principle of ability to pay. The true measure of this ability to pay is discussed in the report of the Committee which came to the conclusion thai in the absence of statistics of national income, the best rough guide would be an index combining (a) net revenue receipts for 1913 and (b) population, with the qualification that the population index should in no case exceed that of the European member possessing the largest population. No recommendation was made as to the (late on which the population should be taken; but as pre-war figures are in many cases worthless owing to territorial changes, it is evident that actual or estimated figures for 1919 must be used. All Member States have been requested to notify to the League their population on December 31, 1919, and: these returns have been used in the calculations which follow.The method of combining these series of figures was not definitely laid down ; but it was suggested that each country's population and revenue might be worked out as percentages of the aggregate population and revenue. This suggestion has been adopted below.It was recognised that this rough index would not give an exact measure of national income, but, except in exceptional circumstances, it was thought that it would place the States in the approximate order of that income.The first two columns of Tables I and II give the figures of population and net revenue respectively: first, in national currencies and, secondly, in dollars (the remaining columns containing further statistical information which has a bearing on the economic position of the various States). In many cases where there have been territorial changes the revenue figures have had to be adjusted on a per capita basis of the transferred population.(*) Thus, it was suggested that a nation's expenditure upon armaments is an indication of the likelihood of its being involved in war and therefore measures its need of the League of Nations. Le Tableau III present les chiffres sous forme de pourcentage rapportes respectivement au chiffre total de la population (sous reserve des remarques deja menlionnees) el a celui des recettes globales. Cest cle ces coefficients qne Ton a tire le chiffre de la colonne finale, chiffre que la Commission propose comme principe de la repartition.La Commission reconnait toutefois que, dans certains cas, particulieremenl quand il existe une grosse population des regions tropicales, le chiffre de la popu-lation constitue un guide moms stir que celui des recettes. Un examen de la colonne des recettes montre qu'il y a 4 ou 5 pays (signales par un asterique) qui ne paraissent pas etre a leur place exacte. Conformement au principe gene-ral donl s'est inspire la Commission, elle propose qu'en pareil Cas, la place des pays en question soil determinee par leurs budge Is, plulot que par les chiffres combines.La Commission avail propose que, lorsque l'ordre des Etats aurail ete eta-l)li, on les repartisse en 7 groupes, comme il est fait maintenant, inais, en l'ab-sence de tableaux complels, elle n'a pu proceder a celte repartition. Certains modes de groupements ont ete proposes au Tableau III, dans le dessein de maintenir approximativement le plus grand nombre possible de pays dans la meme cate-*jorie contributive qu'a present. Ce procede de groupement donne les contribu-tions s'uivantes, par comiparaison avec la methode actuelle (voir page suivante). -Table III shows these results as a percentage of the total ^population (subject lo the limitation already mentioned) and the total revenue receipts respectively. In the final column these indices are combined into the figure which the Committee recommends as the basis of the apportionment.The Committee recognised, however, that in certain cases, particularly where there is a large tropical population, the population figures would be a less reliable guide than revenue receipts. Inspection of the revenue column shows that there are four or five countries (marked with an asterisk) which appear to be out of their proper order. In accordance with the general principle of the Committees recom-mendation it is proposed that in these cases the position of the countries con-cerned should be determined by their budgets rather than by the composite figures.The Committee proposed that when the order had been established they should be divided into seven groups as at present, but in the absence of the completed tables could not lay down the basis of this division.
